thread.title: Scientists find link between comet and asteroid showers and mass extinctions
thread.title_full: Scientists find link between comet and asteroid showers and mass extinctions

title: Scientists find link between comet and asteroid showers and mass extinctions
text:
Crashing comets not likely the cause of Earth's mass extinctions: new research July 30, 2009 
(PhysOrg.com) -- Scientists have debated how many mass extinction events in Earth's history were triggered by a space body crashing into the planet's surface. At least 5 mass extinction events have profoundly changed the history of life on Earth. But a new study led by researchers at the University of Gothenburg shows that plants have been very resilient to those events. Does dark matter cause mass extinctions and geologic upheavals? February 19, 2015

How can dark matter cause chaos on Earth every 30 million years? April 1, 2015 
In 1980, Walter Alvarez and his group at the University of California, Berkeley, discovered a thin layer of clay in the geologic record, which contained an unexpected amount of the rare element iridium. Mass extinction survival is more than just a numbers game August 11, 2015 
Widespread species are at just as high risk of being wiped out as rare ones after global mass extinction events, says new research by UK scientists. Asteroid impact, volcanism were one-two punch for dinosaurs October 1, 2015

Repeatedly throughout Earth's history, giant pools of magma greater than 100 cubic miles in volume have formed a few miles below the surface. Scientists find link between comet and asteroid showers and mass extinctions October 20, 2015 
Mass extinctions occurring over the past 260 million years were likely caused by comet and asteroid showers, scientists conclude in a new study published in Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society. Lathering up with sunscreen may prevent sunburn and protect against cancer, but it is also killing coral reefs around the world. Methane from fracking sites can flow to abandoned wells, new study shows October 20, 2015

Life on Earth likely started 4.1 billion years ago—much earlier than scientists thought October 19, 2015 
UCLA geochemists have found evidence that life likely existed on Earth at least 4.1 billion years ago—300 million years earlier than previous research suggested. The discovery indicates that life may have begun shortly ...
